summary: This is an affidavit filed by attorney Bradley J. Edwards in a Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) enforcement case on behalf of Jane Doe No. 1 and Jane Doe No. 2 against the United States. The affidavit details the victims' unsuccessful efforts to obtain documents and stipulated facts from the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding the non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, and argues for the production of over 13,000 pages of withheld documents. This document is part of a court filing (likely a motion to compel discovery) in the civil case brought by Epstein's victims (Jane Doe No. 1 and Jane Doe No. 2) alleging violations of the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA). It details 24 specific requests for production (RFPs) from the victims' attorneys, seeking documents to prove the U.S. Attorney's Office concealed the non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein from the victims, failed to confer with them, and was potentially improperly influenced by Epstein and his associates. This document is part of a court filing (likely a motion or affidavit) in a civil case (9:08-cv-80736-KAM) concerning victims' rights violations in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. It details the plaintiffs' arguments against the government's assertions of privilege over documents, alleging inadequate privilege logs, failure to prove privilege claims, waiver of confidentiality, and that exceptions (fiduciary duty, crime-fraud-misconduct) apply due to alleged concealment of a non-prosecution agreement from victims. This document is an affidavit filed by attorney Bradley J. Edwards on behalf of Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2, challenging the U.S. Government's assertion of various privileges (attorney-client, deliberative process, investigative, work-product, grand jury) to withhold documents in a Crime Victims' Rights Act lawsuit related to the Jeffrey Epstein prosecution. The affidavit argues the victims have a compelling need for the documents to address the government's 'estoppel' defense and to investigate alleged misconduct in handling the Epstein case, including an OPR investigation. This document is part of a court filing (likely a motion to compel discovery) in a civil case brought by victims (Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2) against the U.S. Government. It details extensive discovery requests seeking documents and information related to the government's investigation and non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, alleging failures to notify victims, improper influences, and potential conflicts of interest among prosecutors. This document is a supplemental request for production filed by victims Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 in their civil case against the United States. It details extensive discovery requests related to the government's handling of the Jeffrey Epstein non-prosecution agreement, alleging misconduct, improper considerations, and violations of the Crime Victims' Rights Act. The filing includes a history of the victims' attempts to obtain discovery and the government's alleged obstruction. This document is part of a civil case (Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 v. United States) filed under the Crime Victims' Rights Act. It contains the plaintiffs' formal discovery requests (including a request for production of documents and a request for admissions) and the U.S. Government's responses. The core issue is whether the government violated victims' rights by negotiating a secret non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein and failing to properly notify the victims. This document is part of a court filing (likely a response to discovery requests or a motion) in a civil case (9:08-cv-80736-KAM) involving Epstein's victims. It contains the U.S. government's admissions and denials regarding the 2008 non-prosecution agreement, victim notification, and potential conflicts of interest involving government attorneys, particularly Bruce Reinhart.

events.title: CVRA Petition Filed
events.description: Bradley J. Edwards filed a petition to enforce the CVRA rights of Jane Doe No. 1 and Jane Doe No. 2 regarding sex offenses committed by Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Initial Court Hearing
events.description: The Court held a hearing on the victims' CVRA petition and discussed the need for a complete record.

events.title: Hearing on Non-Prosecution Agreement Confidentiality
events.description: The Court held a hearing regarding the confidentiality of the non-prosecution agreement and ultimately ordered its production to the victims.

events.title: Email Correspondence Production
events.description: Counsel for Epstein sent approximately 358 pages of email correspondence between criminal defense counsel and the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding the plea agreement to the victims' counsel.

events.title: Civil Lawsuits Settled
events.description: Jane Doe No. 1 and Jane Doe No. 2 settled their civil lawsuits against Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Motion for Summary Judgment Filed
events.description: The victims filed a Motion for Summary Judgment alleging 53 undisputed facts, after the U.S. Attorney's Office declined to agree to a stipulated set of facts.

events.title: Court Orders Document Production
events.description: The Court denied the Government's motion to dismiss, lifted the stay of discovery, and granted the victims' motion to compel production of documents.

events.title: Government's Document Production
events.description: The Government produced 14,825 pages of documents for in camera inspection but turned over only 1,357 pages to the victims, asserting privilege over more than 90% of the documents.

events.title: FBI Sends Misleading Letters to Victims
events.description: The FBI sent letters to Jane Doe No. 1 and Jane Doe No. 2 stating 'this case is currently under investigation,' despite the NPA having already been negotiated, allegedly conveying an inaccurate status.

events.title: Epstein's State Court Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered a guilty plea to state charges, which triggered the federal non-prosecution agreement (NPA) and blocked federal prosecution. The victims allege they were not properly notified beforehand.

events.title: Victims Receive 'Corrected' Notification
events.description: Months after Epstein's guilty plea, the victims received a 'corrected' notification letter from the government regarding the NPA.

events.title: Victims Request OPR Investigation
events.description: The victims requested the DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) investigate whether 'improper influences' were brought to bear during the Epstein prosecution negotiations.

events.title: Alexander Acosta's Letter to Media
events.description: Former U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta sent a letter to the media claiming Epstein launched a 'yearlong assault on the prosecution and the prosecutors.'

events.title: OPR Declines to Assist
events.description: The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility sent a letter to Professor Paul Cassell stating it 'regretted it could not be of assistance' regarding the victims' investigation request.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein and his attorneys signed a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, which included a confidentiality provision barring disclosure to victims.

events.title: FBI Agents Meet with Jane Doe No. 1
events.description: FBI Special Agents E. Nesbitt Kuyrkendall and Jason Richards met in person with victim Jane Doe No. 1, but did not inform her of the existing non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Deceptive FBI Notification Letters Sent
events.description: The FBI sent letters to Jane Doe No. 1 and Jane Doe No. 2 stating the case was 'under investigation,' despite the non-prosecution agreement having been signed months earlier.

events.title: AUSA Villafaña Secures Pro Bono Counsel for Victim
events.description: AUSA Villafaña contacted Meg Garvin to secure pro bono counsel for Jane Doe No. 1 to help her avoid an improper deposition, but did not disclose the non-prosecution agreement to Garvin.

events.title: Victims' Counsel Urges Federal Prosecution
events.description: An attorney for the victims sent a letter to AUSA Villafaña urging the filing of federal charges against Epstein, while still being unaware of the non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Meeting with U.S. Attorney Ferrer
events.description: Co-counsel Paul Cassell and Bradley Edwards met with U.S. Attorney Wifredo Ferrer in Miami to present a letter requesting a personal investigation into the Epstein prosecution and victim treatment.

events.title: Letter Regarding Victim Privacy
events.description: Bradley Edwards sent a letter to the Government stating the victims do not seek identifying information about other victims and that such information should be redacted.

events.title: Filing of Edwards Affidavit
events.description: Bradley J. Edwards executed and filed this affidavit challenging the government's privilege assertions in the CVRA lawsuit.

events.title: Victims request documents from Government
events.description: The victims (Jane Doe #1 and #2) requested that the Government voluntarily provide documents concerning the Epstein case. The Government declined.

events.title: FBI letters to victims
events.description: Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 received letters from the FBI advising them that 'this case is currently under investigation,' despite the existence of a non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Government learns of impending state plea
events.description: The Government learned that Epstein would be entering his plea to state charges on or about June 30, 2008.

events.title: Epstein enters state guilty plea
events.description: Epstein entered a guilty plea to state charges. The document references negotiations about keeping the plea location (e.g., Miami) away from West Palm Beach to avoid victim awareness.

events.title: Attorney's letter urging federal charges
events.description: Bradley J. Edwards, attorney for the victims, sent a letter to the Government urging the filing of federal charges against Epstein, allegedly without knowledge of the existing non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Initial victim notification
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office provided notice to Jane Doe #1 of some terms of the agreement with Epstein.

events.title: Corrected victim notification
events.description: The victims received a 'corrected' notification letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding the agreement with Epstein.

events.title: Victims request conflict investigation
events.description: The victims sent a letter to the U.S. Attorney's Office requesting an investigation into 'improper influences' during the Epstein negotiations, leading to a referral to the Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR).

events.title: OPR declines further assistance
events.description: The Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) sent a letter to the victims indicating they would not provide any further assistance regarding allegations of improper influences in the Epstein case.

events.title: Acosta and Black Media Letters
events.description: Former U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta sent a letter to news media claiming Epstein launched 'a yearlong assault on the prosecution.' Epstein's attorney Roy Black sent a responsive letter.

events.title: Epstein's State Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered a guilty plea to state charges, which the victims allege was the consummation of a non-prosecution agreement barring federal prosecution.

events.title: Victims' Initial Discovery Requests
events.description: Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2, through counsel, filed their initial request for production of documents to the government regarding the Epstein case.

events.title: Government Files Motion to Dismiss and Stay
events.description: The government filed a motion to dismiss the victims' case and an ex parte motion to stay discovery, rather than producing requested documents.

events.title: Court Denies Government's Motion to Dismiss
events.description: The court denied the government's motion to dismiss and lifted the stay of discovery proceedings, allowing the case to move forward.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida entered into a non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein, resolving the federal investigation into sex offenses.

events.title: FBI Meeting with Jane Doe #1
events.description: FBI agents met with Jane Doe #1. The government admits agents explained Epstein would plead guilty to state charges, register as a sex offender, and she could seek damages.

events.title: Draft Notification Letter to Defense
events.description: A. Marie Villafana of the USAO sent a draft victim notification letter to Epstein's attorney, Jay Lefkowitz. The letter stated the investigation was complete and outlined the NPA terms.

events.title: Misleading Letters Sent to Victims
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sent letters to Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 stating 'this case is currently under investigation,' despite having already signed the NPA with Epstein.

events.title: Filing of Discovery Requests
events.description: Bradley J. Edwards and Paul G. Cassell filed formal discovery requests (Request for Production and Request for Admissions) on behalf of Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2.

events.title: Signing of Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida entered into a non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, blocking federal prosecution for specified sex offenses.

events.title: OPR Investigation into Epstein Agreement
events.description: The Justice Department's Office of Professional Responsibility collected information about potential misconduct relating to the Epstein non-prosecution agreement, including Reinhart's involvement and possible conflicts of interest.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of Florida
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office withheld over 13,000 pages of documents from the victims, asserting privilege on more than 90% of the documents produced for in camera inspection.
Email correspondence revealed the U.S. Attorney's Office took 'extreme steps' to avoid prosecuting Epstein and to keep victims from learning about the non-prosecution agreement.
The victims attempted for years to reach a stipulated set of facts with the Government, but the Government repeatedly reversed course and ultimately declined to agree to any facts.

The Court has indicated it will consider an 'estoppel' defense from the Government, which involves assessing allegations of a 'deliberate conspiracy' between Epstein and federal prosecutors to keep victims in the dark.
Former Justice Department officials Bruce Reinhart and Alex Acosta, who had information about the Epstein case, ignored requests for interviews from the victims' attorney.

The victims' attorneys allege a 'deliberate conspiracy' between Jeffrey Epstein and federal prosecutors to keep the non-prosecution agreement (NPA) secret from the victims until after Epstein's state guilty plea.

The document claims former prosecutor Bruce Reinhart filed a false affidavit about his knowledge of the Epstein case and later set up a law firm at Epstein's personal business address, suggesting a potential ethical violation.

Epstein allegedly used his 'significant social and political connections,' including former President Bill Clinton, Prince Andrew, and Alan Dershowitz, to lobby the Justice Department for a more favorable plea deal after signing the NPA.
The FBI sent letters to victims in January 2008 stating the case was 'under investigation,' which the filing argues was highly misleading because the NPA had already been negotiated.
The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida was allegedly 'conflicted out' of handling certain aspects of the Epstein case, potentially related to its treatment of the victims.
The U.S. Attorney's Office entered into a non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein in September 2007 that included a provision barring disclosure of the agreement to the victims.

The FBI, potentially at the direction of the U.S. Attorney's Office, sent letters to victims in 2008 stating the case was 'under investigation,' which was deceptive as the case had already been resolved by the non-prosecution agreement.
Prosecutors, including A. Marie Villafaña, allegedly concealed the existence of the non-prosecution agreement from the victims and their legal counsel, even when securing pro bono help for a victim.
The document alleges potential misconduct by former government attorneys Bruce Reinhart and Matthew Menchel regarding their subsequent relationships with Epstein or Epstein-related entities.
The government's privilege log for withheld documents is argued to be inadequate and in violation of a court order, failing to properly identify documents and justify privilege claims.

The affidavit argues the government improperly asserted attorney-client privilege over documents related to 'victim notification' and communications with Epstein's attorneys, and that a 'fiduciary exception' should apply.

It reveals an Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) investigation was opened at the victims' request to investigate the handling of the Epstein case and treatment of victims, and that many documents about this investigation are being withheld.

The document states the victims need the withheld materials to counter the government's 'estoppel' defense, which the court noted implicates an assessment of 'a deliberate conspiracy between Epstein and federal prosecutors to keep the victims in the dark.'
The affidavit contends that investigative privilege factors (under Frankenhauser v. Rizzo) weigh in favor of disclosing the information to the victims.
It clarifies that the victims are not seeking identifying information about other victims and have requested the government redact such details from any produced documents.

The victims allege the FBI developed an 'overwhelming' case against Epstein for operating a criminal enterprise that used paid employees to find and bring minor girls to him, including an 82-page prosecution memo and 53-page draft indictment.

The discovery requests seek extensive documentation on alleged efforts by Epstein and his associates (including Bill Clinton, Prince Andrew, Alan Dershowitz, and Ken Starr) to lobby the Justice Department for a more favorable non-prosecution agreement.

There are serious allegations of improper relationships between government officials and Epstein, specifically focusing on former prosecutor Bruce Reinhart allegedly joining Epstein's payroll after key decisions were made.

The document details how the Government and Epstein allegedly worked together to keep the non-prosecution agreement secret from victims, including negotiating the plea location to be outside West Palm Beach to avoid press and victim awareness.
The Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) opened an inquiry based on victim allegations of 'improper influences' but later informed the victims it would not provide further assistance.
The victims allege the Epstein non-prosecution agreement was based on 'considerations apart from the merits' and involved violations of law, ethics, and victims' rights policies.

The document requests all correspondence between a wide array of government prosecutors (e.g., Acosta, Sloman) and Epstein's defense team (e.g., Black, Dershowitz) and 'agents' like Bill Clinton and Prince Andrew.
It alleges the government engaged in a pattern of delay and obstruction, refusing to produce discovery for over 17 months despite court orders.
The request seeks information on any donations, employment assistance, or other 'valuable consideration' Epstein may have offered to government officials to influence the plea deal.
The filing is part of a civil case under the Crime Victims' Rights Act, where the victims seek to uncover the government's handling of the Epstein prosecution.

The U.S. Government admits that after learning of planned victim notifications, Jeffrey Epstein's attorneys objected, and the U.S. Attorney's Office considered those objections, which altered the scope, nature, and timing of notifications to victims.

The government admits the non-prosecution agreement with Epstein contained a provision anticipating it would not be made part of any public record and required notice to Epstein before any disclosure under FOIA.
The government admits that, at least in part due to objections from Epstein's lawyers, Jane Doe #1 was not told about the non-prosecution agreement until after it was signed.
